title: Boxer Manju Rani's Spirited Debut Effort Bags Her Silver At The World Championships
text:
In her maiden World Championships' appearance, Manju Rani stole the show as she fought with all her might on her way to a silver medal win.

The 19-year-old from Haryana, who represented Punjab in the Nationals after failing to get a break from her own state, was the lone Indian, among four semifinalists, to make the finals of the mega-event in Ulan-Ude, Russia.

She came agonisingly close to winning old in her debut at the tournament, but eventually had for a light flyweight (48kg) silver medal after losing to Russia's Ekaterina Paltceva by a very close margin.

AFP

After surprising everyone with her ability and making her way to the finals, the 19-year-old punched way above her expectations and made her way to the summit clash.

In what would have been a historic moment had she clinched gold, a silver in your first outing at the World Championships is no less a remarkable achievement.

Hailing from the Rithal village in Rohtak, life was tough for Rani. She lost her father, a BSF man, to cancer in 2010 and was raised, along with four of her other siblings, by her mother Ishwanti Devi.

"I started as a kabaddi player but that's a team sport and credit is shared. Boxing attracted me because it's an individual sport, the glory is all yours alone," she recalled.

AP

"My mother was very supportive of my career choice. She backed me to the hilt," she added.

It also helped that she had Olympic medal winners in Vijender Singh and MC Mary Kom to look up to.

"Vijender bhaiya and Mary didi have inspired so many and I am one of them. Just looking at what they have achieved makes you want to work harder. I used to watch them and feel good about taking up this sport," she told PTI.

It is a massive feat for the young prodigy, and one that she will never forget. The medal win will also be a massive boost for not only her confidence, but also the career going ahead.

(With Inputs From PTI)
